awd_titl_txt: Workshops: Broadening Participation of Historically Black Colleges and Universities in the NSF Research Traineeship and Innovations in Graduate Education Programs
awd_abstract_narration:
This award to Jackson State University is supported by the National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) and Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) programs. The project team will bring together members of the Carnegie Doctoral Universities High Research (R2) Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), experts in graduate education, graduate students, other HBCUs, and NSF program officers.  Two workshops will be organized to address challenges related to increasing the number of STEM Ph.Ds. from underserved populations and providing support and training to investigators from the participating institutions to generate creative proposals for the NRT and IGE programs.   The workshops are intended to provide information, understanding, and training on how new graduate models can be created to increase the recruitment, retention, and graduation of minority Ph.D. students.  

This project endeavors to develop strategies and critical recommendations that will address growing national concerns about the number of African Americans applying to Ph.D. programs in STEM. By promoting the close interaction of NSF program officers with a coalition of R2 HBCU graduate education stakeholders, the workshops are intended to increase interest in and awareness of the NRT and IGE programs and the number of proposals submitted by R2 HBCU institutions. The specific goals of the workshops are to 1) understand and investigate how to leverage relationships between R2 HBCU institutions and the NRT and IGE programs; 2) investigate current models and best practices between the coalition of R2 HBCUs that may support recruitment, retention, and positioning of Ph.D. STEM students into the U.S. workforce, and 3) provide proposal writing training to support the production of competitive proposals to the NRT and IGE programs to support these models. Additionally, this project will be a path forward to filling in the gaps in outreach to and communications with R2 HBCUs by the NSF, which can lead to greater diversity in the STEM fields.  The model that results from this project can then be tested and applied to other NSF programs where R2 HBCUs are underrepresented in funding.  

The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new potentially transformative models for STEM graduate education training. The program is dedicated to effective training of STEM graduate students in high priority interdisciplinary or convergent research areas through comprehensive traineeship models that are innovative, evidence-based, and aligned with changing workforce and research needs. The Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) program is focused on research in graduate education. The goals of IGE are to pilot, test, and validate innovative approaches to graduate education and to generate the knowledge required to move these approaches into the broader community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project aimed to bring together faculty, researchers, and administrators from Carnegie Classification High Research Activity (R2) Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) to develop ideas, approaches and models for increasing the number of STEM doctoral students from under-represented populations.  The project pursues three objectives: (1) To understand and investigate how relationships among R2 HBCUs can be leveraged to fully utilize the NRT and IGE programs; (2) To investigate current models and best practices within the coalition of R2 HBCUs that optimally support recruitment, retention and transitioning of STEM doctoral students into the U.S. workforce; and (3) To provide proposal writing training to increase the number of proposals submitted to the NRT and IGE programs.

 

This project hosted four impactful events: NRT Program Workshop, IGE Program Workshop, NRT-IGE Workshop, and a HBCU Graduate School Deans Roundtable Conversation. We connected 219 participants from 17 institutions. (These included representatives from HBCUs: Alcorn State, Delaware State, Howard, Jackson State, Morgan State, Mississippi Valley State, North Carolina A&T, Southern-Baton Rouge, Southern-New Orleans, Southern University System, Tennessee State, Texas Southern and University of Maryland Eastern Shore.). Our first three workshops featured expert presentations, discussions, and insights from current NSF program officers, successful PIs, and former NSF program officers. Participants refined their proposal ideas through small-group and one-on-one discussions. The Council of Graduate Schools shared valuable support and resources, and we encouraged graduate students to apply for the NSF Graduate Research Fellowship Program. The Deans Roundtable Conversation brought together HBCU PIs who shared their experiences with newly-awarded and successfully-completed IGE proposals. We also explored the Council of Graduate Schools' IGE HUB and helped deans develop strategies to leverage the IGE and NRT programs for their graduate school success.

 

Post-event surveys provided definitive feedback on the workshops' effectiveness in conveying information. We videotaped all presentations and activities, then made them publicly available on our website alongside supporting materials: https://www.jsums.edu/isjrr/ige-nrt-workshops/. Additionally, we shared these resources with both workshop participants and the Council of Graduate Schools, securing their inclusion in the IGE Hub and broadening our reach.

 

This project boosted awareness of the NSF IGE and NRT programs among R2 HBCUs. It connected HBCU participants with current and former NSF program officers who shared valuable insights into the proposal writing process, both generally and specifically for IGE and NRT. Participants learned from successful NSF and IGE award recipients how to structure their teams and write winning proposals. The grantee extended its partnership with the Council for Graduate Schools' IGE Hub, offering its expertise to conference attendees. This effort created a vibrant community of practice for IGE and NRT proposal writers. The program fostered strong relationships between HBCU participants and NSF program officers. It also facilitated groundbreaking interdisciplinary and multi-institutional collaborations between STEM and social sciences disciplines. Two proposals from HBCUs were submitted directly as a result of this program.  One proposal was funded, Evaluating an Innovative, Structured Teaching Assistantship Program: Impacts on Student Success and Career Readiness (Award # 2325659).

 

The workshops also offered exceptional training opportunities for junior faculty members. Through direct engagement with NSF program officers, successful PIs, and experienced proposal writers, junior faculty gained invaluable insights into the proposal development and submission. The hands-on experience in refining proposal ideas, coupled with personalized feedback during small-group and one-on-one discussions, empowered these emerging scholars to enhance their grant-writing skills. Furthermore, the workshops served as a platform for junior faculty to network with peers and senior mentors across various institutions, fostering professional growth and encouraging collaborative research efforts that could lead to future funding successes.
